awd_titl_txt: The Causes and Consequences of Variation in Dispersal Distance
awd_abstract_narration:
Like people, wild animals and plants can spend their lives close to where they were born or move away. Scientists call these lifetime movements "dispersal". While short-distance dispersal is common, long-distance dispersal is rare. Long-distance dispersal, however, plays an important role in nature -- it can help species survive when their habitat is destroyed, and can spread genes that they need to adapt to new conditions. Long-distance dispersal can also allow invasive species to spread quickly, leading to significant management costs and threatening native species. Scientists do not fully understand the factors that cause differences in dispersal distance, in part because it is difficult to track long-distance dispersers. This research will help people understand the causes and consequences of differences in dispersal distance by focusing on a salamander that lives in small, mountain streams. Because salamanders disperse along streams, and because even long-distance dispersers don't go very far (less than 500 meters), it is possible to collect information on dispersal (distance, timing, conditions before and after) that would be difficult and expensive to collect in other species. With this information, scientists and managers can better promote dispersal by native species, or prevent dispersal by invasive species. 

This research will test whether dispersal distance affects individual performance (survival and growth), and how environmental factors (habitat stability and predation) influence those effects. The researcher will then test whether individual performance consequences predict population-level variation in dispersal distances (i.e., dispersal kernels), associated morphological, behavioral, and physiological phenotypes, and emergent patterns of population connectivity and range expansion. Because the research questions center on fundamental performance consequences, scaling relationships, and biogeographic processes, results will be informative across taxa. In particular, this work will help bridge plant and animal studies of dispersal by filling a common gap in our understanding of the scaling of dispersal data -- from individual traits to population-level dispersal distributions, and further to landscape and biogeographic consequences.

por.por_cntn:
Like people, animals and plants can spend their lives close to their origin or move away. Scientists call these lifetime movements dispersal. Short-distance dispersal is common, but long-distance dispersal is rare. Long-distance dispersal, however, plays an important role in nature. Long-distance dispersal can help species survive when habitats shift and can spread genes that they need to adapt to new conditions. Long-distance dispersal can also allow invasive species to spread quickly, leading to significant management costs and threatening native species. Scientists do not fully understand the factors that cause differences in dispersal distance, in part because it is difficult to track long-distance dispersers. This research focused on salamanders that live in small, mountain streams to gain new insight on what allows animals to disperse long distances, what motivates these dispersal events, and how long-distance dispersal affects genetic relationships among animals. Because salamanders disperse along streams, and because even long-distance dispersers don’t go very far (< 500 m), it is possible to collect information on dispersal (distance, timing, conditions before and after) that would be difficult and expensive to collect in other species.

 

We discovered that salamanders that dispersed the farthest along streams had longer limbs but swam at slower speeds than those that dispersed short distances. The poor swimming performance of long‐distance dispersers likely resulted from the drag caused by long limbs – the fastest swimmers had short limbs. This showed that long-distance dispersal has a cost because the same trait that allows long-distance dispersal reduces performance in another important aspect of salamander behavior. This tradeoff may help to explain why long-distance dispersal is rare in salamanders and most other species.

 

So, what motivates a salamander to disperse long distances, and why do we see those long-legged dispersers in the population? Our findings show that the salamanders that disperse long distances are those that start out in the riskiest locations, where they are most likely to die if they do not disperse. This response seems logical. Most humans would probably choose to relocate when faced with similar risks, but salamanders give us the first evidence of this response in an animal. As long as salamanders continue to occupy risky environments, we would expect to see long-distance dispersal and long-legged individuals in the population.

 

Other scientists have hypothesized that the risk of inbreeding acts as an important motivator for long-distance dispersal. Specifically, long-distance dispersal is expected to reduce the chances that an individual will mate with a relative, and thereby reduce the likelihood that offspring will suffer from the negative effects of matings between related parents. We found that long-distance dispersal does not necessarily serve this purpose. In some streams, long-distance dispersers ended up surrounded by unrelated individuals, thus escaping the risk of inbreeding. But in other streams, long-distance dispersers ended up surrounded by salamanders that were still close relatives. From these results, we concluded that reducing inbreeding risk may be a benefit of long-distance dispersal, but it is probably not the most important motivator.

 

In addition to these discoveries, this project helped to support four graduate students and eight researcher assistants, including undergraduates and postgraduates. The graduate students were based at the University of Montana but spent their summers at the field sites in New Hampshire, as part of a diverse and dynamic community of researchers. Two of these graduate students have now completed their dissertations and are employed in the fields of ecology and conservation. Most of the research assistants also came from outside of New Hampshire, bringing with them new research ideas and life experiences. Many of the people involved in this research devoted time to share their findings with the public and other scientists, helping to increase awareness of the interesting animals that live in our smallest streams.
